user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of SHA1Input:
```c
static enum SHA1_RESULT
SHA1Input (struct SHA1Context *context, const unsigned char *message_array,
           unsigned length)
{
  if (! length)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
  }
  if (! context || ! message_array)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_NULL;
  }
  if (context->computed)
  {
    context->corrupted = 1;
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  if (context->corrupted)
  {
    return SHA1_RESULT_STATE_ERROR;
  }
  while (length-- && ! context->corrupted)
  {
    context->message_block[context->message_block_index++]
      = (*message_array & 0xFF);
    context->length_low += 8;
    if (context->length_low == 0)
    {
      context->length_high++;
      if (context->length_high == 0)
      {
        context->corrupted = 1;
      }
    }
    if (context->message_block_index == 64)
    {
      SHA1ProcessMessageBlock (context);
    }
    message_array++;
  }
  return SHA1_RESULT_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rule forbids modifying function parameters themselves. The two reported fragments modify parameter variables (the scalar parameter 'length' and the pointer parameter 'message_array') and therefore must be investigated. Other modifications in the function operate on objects pointed to by parameters or on local state and are allowed by the rule: e.g. context->message_block_index++, context->length_low, context->length_high, and writes into context->message_block modify the object referred to by the pointer parameter 'context' (permitted). The dereference (*message_array & 0xFF) only reads the pointee (permitted). Calls such as SHA1ProcessMessageBlock(context) do not modify the parameter variable itself. Hence no other fragments need investigation for Rule 17.8.
